1.label: section_header
1.text: 1. FROM THE GREEK INTO ARABIC AND FROM ARABIC INTO LATIN

1.label: text
1.text: ‘The Optics of Ptolemy was first published in Latin by Gilberto Govi in 1885,’ but it remained unknown to historians of art and perspective until 1957, when Decio Gioseffi mentioned it for the first time.* However, this scholar limited his analysis to just a few lines of paragraph 4 of book III, a paragraph that will also be analyzed in this chapter. From that point on, Ptolemy's Optics has not, as far as I know, been taken into consideration by historians of art and perspective.

1.label: text
1.text: The principal reason that scholars have abstained from studying Ptolemy's Optics is especially because of the diffi- culty of the Latin language in which the work has come down to us. The admiral Eugenius of Sicily, who lived in the second half of the twelfth century at the court of the Norman kings in Palermo, translated Ptolemy's Optics from Arabic into Latin; the Arabic version was, in its turn, a translation from the Greek, the language in which Ptolemy, living in the first half of the second century A.p., had written the work. Govi was the first to rightly underscore that the Latin is quite often obscure because it was a literal translation from Arabic and that the geometric concepts

1.label: page_footer
1.text: sot 99/10.1017/€809781139198905.007 Pushed online by Cambridge University Press

2.label: text
2.text: are often improper as a result of the translator's ignorance of the correct expressions needed to be able to translate them from Arabic into Latin. There is no known documentation regarding the existence of the Arabic text from which the Latin is derived, nor is there any information regarding the original Greek text from which the Arabic is derived.

2.label: text
2.text: These same difficulties of interpretation were expressed by Albert Lejeune,’ who spoke of a translation of a translation, such that it could discourage any reader in good faith, and by A. Mark Smith,‘ who spoke of a text difficult to penetrate, being so tortuous and confused that it is often incomprehensible.’

2.label: text
2.text: Again, it is worth noting that both Lejeune and Smith, in providing their first translations in French and in English, took upon themselves an onerous task, not unlike that of paleogra- phers, when these scholars attempt to decipher deep layers of a palimpsest.‘ For this reason, Lejeune and Smith were forced to adhere scrupulously to an exegetic reconstruction of a very difficult text

2.label: text
2.text: ‘My task, however, has been first of all to take a look at the entire reconstructed work of the Ptolemaic text by Lejeune and Smith, then successively to go beyond it in an attempt to specifically illustrate some passages of the Optics with draw- ings, and finally to compare them in modern terms with the geometric theories of representation.’

2.label: text
2.text: Let us begin with Sermo Tertius De Opticis Tholomei, that is to say “The Third Speech on the Optics of Ptolemy” ~ also known as “The Third Book (or Sermon)” on the Optics, according to how we prefer to translate the Latin word Sermo ~ naturally limiting our attention to an analysis of flat mirrors only.*

2.text: 2. THE THREE PRINCIPLES RELATIVE TO THE SCIENCE OF MIRRORS

2.label: text
2.text: Since, therefore, in every field in which one turns to science there is the necessity of a number of general principles, that is

3.label: text
3.text: to say, how the objects place themselves, in an unfailing and indisputable manner, in front of us, effectively as well as cor- rectly, from the demonstrations of which one can make deduc- tions, we must say that the principles that one requires for the science of mirrors are specifically three, and that these are primary elements of knowledge that are possible to learn by oneself. The first [principle] is that by which one recognizes that the objects, which can be seen in mirrors, appear in con- formity with the direction of the visual ray, which falls upon the objects by means of its own reflection. This [reflection] is verified in conformity with the position of the pupil with respect to the mirror. The second [principle], without a doubt, is that by which one recognizes that the single [points] that one sees in the mirrors appear on the perpendicular line that falls from the object that is seen onto the surface of the mir ror and penetrates it. The third [principle], instead, is that by which one recognizes that the position of the bent ray, which is found between the pupil and the mirror and between the mirror and the thing that is to be seen, is such that each of these two [segments] arrives at the point in respect to which the break occurs, while they contain, parting from the mirror, angles equal with the perpendicular line that exits from the very same point.”

3.label: text
3.text: Here the general principles relative to the science of flat mirrors are described, and it is specified that they are pri- mary notions that one can verify by oneself. The first thing that stands out as evident is that the mirrors constitute a field in which one may turn to science. This is an authentic invitation to experimental verification as to how objects are distributed in front of us in an unfailing and indisputable manner.

8.text: ‘The topics relative to the principles set forth will now be made manifest through the objects that appear, as we will show.

8.label: text
8.text: In effect, for all mirrors, we have discovered that if on the surface of each of these we will have marked the points in the places in which the objects to be observed appear, and we will have connected them, certainly the form of the object to be seen will not then appear. Certainly after, when we will have composed one object after another and we will have turned our gaze toward the places investigated, the marked points and the form of the thing to be observed will appear together, in conformity with the alignment of the origin of the visual ray. And when we will have raised upon the surfaces of the mir- rors at right angles some long objects in a straight line and the distance will be established, the images of those objects will appear in a straight line: that is, these same ones in truth and in addition to the objects that are observed."

9.text: In this paragraph two invitations can be found. The first consists of marking ~ or, better yet, tracing ~ the points that appear on the mirror and then opportunely interweaving them. ‘The second consists of observing the traced images in a way that makes them coincide with the reflected images, because, after having completed the operation of tracing, it will no longer be possible to have the marked points and the reflected images coincide, without conforming oneself to the alignment of the origin of the visual ray and to the distance of this origin from the mirror.

9.label: text
9.text: Therefore, once the tracing of the points has been realized, one cannot choose another pupil O°, or another eye, in order to observe the traced image (Fig. 88). Only from point ©, in fact, will one see the traced images coincide with those reflected, and the conditions as described in the previously analyzed “third principle” will be respected. The point A’, in fact, observed from 0°, would not be seen in A" but would distance itself

11.text: From both of these things [is derived]: that the object to be seen must appear in the mirror at the place of the point in which are connected the visual ray and the perpendicular line, which falls from the object to be observed onto the mirror; that also the site of these two aforementioned lines is found on the same surface because the one [of the two] meets the other; and that the surface itself, in which they find themselves, is orthogonal to the surface of the mirror at right angles, because one of these two [lines] is perpendicular to the surface of the mirror; and that the visual ray, when it will have fractured in the direction of the object to be observed, finds itself on the same surface of which we have spoken; and that the perpendicular line, exit- ing from the point of reflection on the surface of the mirror, is the common distinction of all the different surfaces that form themselves around the reflection of the visual rays."

12.text: After having analyzed, in the preceding paragraph, the two fundamental operations of tracing and of observation accord- ing to the origin of the ray and according to the distance, Ptolemy sets forth the five deductions that are obtained from these operations (Fig. 89). Such deductions, which we have already anticipated in part in order to better introduce the drawings examined, are as follows:

13.label: list_item

13.label: list_item

13.text: 5. MONOCULAR VISION AS ConpITIO. Sine Qua Non

13.label: text
13.text: Furthermore, [all this] is verified in this manner since the dis- position of the eyes is constituted as if the one saw the other in the same instant, which is what happens since from the one

13.label: page_footer
13.text: sot 99/10.1017/€809781139198905.007 Pushed online by Cambridge University Press

14.label: text
14.text: and from the other the vision falls on a unique and same point between those [two] that are on the mirror. If it does not occur in this way, it transpires that neither of these is aware of the other, and that signifies that the rays of sight reflect themselves from one part and from the other. From these things, it results also that the reflection is at equal angles. There will be in fact a single and same angle because of the loss of one of the two rays on the mirror and because of the reflection of one of the two [rays] parting from the mirror.'*

14.label: text
14.text: In this paragraph, it is specified that the disposition of the eyes is constituted as if the one sees the other in the same instant onasingle and same point between the two that one sees on the mirror. If this were not so, the eyes would operate separately, each for itself in such a way as to have a double reflection: one for each eye. Thus it is clear that the double reflection did not exist for the ancients, as it does not exist for us, because this entailed, then as now, the visual alteration to which has been given the name dyplopia.

14.label: text
14.text: Therefore, the fundamental notion that is at the base of vision remains certified: the cyclopic unity of sight, with the consequent coincidence of the two optical axes in one princi- pal visual axis. This unity, scientifically linked to the loss, in the reflection of the mirrors, of one of the two optical axes,"” becomes the conditio sine qua non, placed at the base of the the- ory of vision, and allows us to mark a single eye O, or one sole pupil, instead of two (Fig. 89).

14.label: text
14.text: Let us now analyze the motivations that justify the presence of the points O' and 0” that we have marked and what are the effective meanings that Ptolemy gives them.

14.text: 6. THE DOUBLE AND Opposite VIEW, THE NECESSITY OF A SIGN

14.label: text
14.text: Since [the rays] proceed also perpendicularly from [the posi- tion of] sight to the mirror, the image will occur according to

15.text: the dimension rendered of the established object in conformity with the gaze, which is set straightforward. Each of these rays [orthogonal to the mirror], in fact, is seen on the perpendicular line that passes through the pupil. The rays in fact that transit through one who looks and that extend themselves toward the pupil parting from the origin, whose position is found within, at the center of the spherical globe, are all perpendicular to the surface of the pupil, which assumes the nature of a curved mirror, with a form and configuration of its own. For this rea- son we are able to know also the forms of things, exactly as the sight positions receive them, which are, on one side and on the other, opposite. When the reflection, which should occur from the objects to be observed to the pupils according to a direc- tion and an opposition, is transferred to the mirrors, since it conserves the disposition that would be from the pupils to the objects themselves, there will be at this point the coincidence also of the line that proceeds from the [position of] sight with the same ray that, in that case, there is between the pupil and the object to be observed. It is just as it occurs in the things that appear opposite from one part and from the other, when the gaze will fall at right angles onto the mirror and it reflects upon itself. Thus there will be a sign of this [reflection], in conformity to which occurs the appearance of the object, one only in the quantity and in the position, which is that through which [the ray] arranges itself in a straight line perpendicu- larly to the mirror and to the pupil. And consequently there will be a double and opposite view of the object in the dimen- sion rendered and in characteristics: one that certainly goes from the [position of] sight to the thing that appears, the other that goes instead from the thing that appears to the [position of] sight."

15.label: text
15.text: This is the key paragraph, which constitutes a true turning point in the interpretation and in the scientific collocation of Ptolemy's Optics within the outline of the history of perspec tive. The sequence of the passages is as follows.

15.label: text
15.text: Since the visual rays (Fig. 89) can proceed also perpendic- ularly from the position of sight to the mirror (the ray 00" is perpendicular to the mirror), the image of the object to be

16.text: observed will be a function of the gaze that is set straightfor- ward in respect to the mirror. But each point of these orthogo- nal rays, including that [the point] that individuates the center of the pupil, as specified by Ptolemy, is seen on the perpendic- ular line that passes through the pupil orthogonally to the mir- ror. In other words, the pupil, or the eye, must have a proper reflection, that is to say, a virtual correspondent of its own beyond the mirror on the orthogonal line to the mirror, pass- ing through the pupil

16.label: text
16.text: One could not better grasp the importance of the rays orthogonal to the surface of a flat mirror if not through the reflection of the pupil itself. Being in front of a mirror, in fact, the real pupil indicates to us the exact position from where one perceives that given vision which we see in the mirror. But we immediately realize that the pupil is reflected onto the mirror upon the extension of the ray orthogonal from the pupil to the mirror, individuating the virtual pupil whose distance from the mirror, on the opposite side, is exactly as much as the dis- tance of the real one from the mirror. We are able, therefore, to draw the corresponding virtual 0" of O from the other part of the mirror, onto the orthogonal line through O to the mirror, so that 0'0" is equal to 0'0.

16.label: text
16.text: But pay close attention, again says Ptolemy, for since the perpendicular line through the pupil to the mirror, or through the eye, intercepts the mirror, it reflects itself and returns on itself, and, returning upon itself, it is well that, in the point where the perpendicular line from the position of sight strikes the mirror, there should be a “sign” (a nutus, says the Latin) of the point of this reflection. This is the point “in conformity to which the apparition of the object occurs” (a quo fit apparitio rei). But Ptolemy specifies again that this point must be unus in numero et situ, that is to say “one only in quantity and in position.” The sign must be one only “in quantity” because the eyes, as we have seen, even though they are two and both appear in the mirror, create just one single reflection of the image; it must be one only “in position” because that point must be placed upon the mirror where the perpendicular from

17.text: ‘The segments of the visual rays, which we have traced from the real pupil toward the image on the mirror, and their exten- sion, onto the points of the virtual object, form a first pyramid with vertex O. The form that we have traced, or the reflected image, must therefore be understood asa straightforward image of the virtual object. Naturally, it is this image, which is after all that of perspective, that Ptolemy wants to develop. We will examine, in the paragraphs that follow, what is implied by the reflected image that is “associated” with the straightforward vision of the virtual object. The segments of the reflected rays, instead, which part from objective points in order to reach the images on the mirror, once prolonged starting from the mir- ror, converge beyond the mirror in the vertex 0" of a second pyramid.

18.label: text
18.text: But let us again pause for a moment upon the fact that Ptolemy felt the necessity to put that sign, or rather that nutus, there where the ray orthogonal through the pupil to the mirror

19.text: is fractured upon the mirror itself. Though the Latin text pres- ents evident interpretative difficulties and is not easy reading, as Lejeune himself affirms,"* it stands out in any case and is immediately evident that here are introduced two great con- cepts of modern perspective:

19.label: list_item
19.text: 1, Ptolemy’s mucus is none other than the principal vanishing point.

19.label: list_item
19.text: 2. The orthogonal ray, which goes from the pupil to the mir- ror, is none other than the principal ray.

19.label: text
19.text: For a long time I have been in search of further clarifications of this “sign.” Every effort has been futile. In the Latin text that Lejeune quotes later, I have not found any reference to that nutus.

19.label: text
19.text: In the end, after having attentively reread several times the paragraphs that precede paragraph 16 as well as those which follow it, my attention fell upon the Latin text that goes from <secundum id quod pretaxavimus up to penes rem vere videndam ad prope>, which is quoted in Lejeune twice. It is, in fact, part of paragraph 1 and of the entire following paragraph 13, as well as of the entire paragraph 60.

19.label: text
19.text: In this text, there is a phrase that caught my attention: et conservat hanc metam cum eo quod ex utrisque apparet, which translates “and conserve this meta [destination point] with that which from both [the conformations] appears.” I was unable to find any connection of this phrase in Lejeune with the texts that immediately follow or precede the paragraphs 1 and 13; in the same way, I was unable to find any connection of the same phrase with the texts that immediately follow or precede the paragraph 60.

19.label: text
19.text: I maintain that the entire passage that goes from <secundum id quod pretaxavimus up to penes rem vere videndam ad prope> must be placed immediately after paragraph 16, where it con- stitutes, as we will now see, the missing link. Let us give it the name paragraph 16a, and let us read it attentively in continuity with the text preceding it

20.label: section_header
20.text: 7. THE ASSOCIATED IMAGE, THE VIRTUAL OBJECT, AND THE META OR THE PRINCIPAL VANISHING POINT

20.label: text
20.text: And consequently there will be a double and opposite view of the object in the dimension rendered and in its character- istics: one that certainly goes from the [position of] sight to the thing that appears, the other that goes instead from the thing that appears to the [position of] sight, in conformity with that which we have discussed before, where it was said that the images of things erected upon the mirrors at right angles are seen according to straight lines without folds and appear positioned on the same side toward which the objects move. In conformity with the scientific concept, in fact, that within the mirror we perceive that which appears in a straight line, and consequently we come to know the position of the object to be seen, we proceed in this manner also for the finding of the position of the virtual, apparent form, since the associ- ated image is seen straightforward, according to the one and the other conformation, which is to say, of the conformation of the object placed in front [of the position of sight] and of that which really appears, and conserves this meta [destination point] with that which from both [conformations] appear, as if all [the points] were seen according to an opposite position in respect to the side of its own apparent position. Therefore, a straight quantity appears straight. At preestablished distances, then, when a true image will be found on a straight line and the object will be arranged at right angles to the mirrors, it is necessary that that which appears of one side is found at the same time in conformity to both [the views] on a single straight line, And if a same segment will appear erect to the surface of a mirror and its apparition will be found on a straight line, again it will be seen erect upon the same surface, so that there is no distinction between this one and the entire extension, as if the objects to be observed were arranged in real places, naturally those which are arranged according to that which regards the mirrors in conformity to the things that are seen and to their

21.label: text
21.text: forms, after having maintained, for each of the two positions, the meta [destination point] of that which appears in the object to be observed correctly according to the proximity.”

21.label: text
21.text: In order to better understand the text, we should once again observe the two eyes, the two cubes, and their image traced upon the mirror (Fig. 90), which we will call the “associated object” (res congregata).

21.label: text
21.text: The scientific theory of tracing upon the mirrors assists us in two ways:

21.label: list_item
21.text: 1. We can see the original cube as if it were placed straightfor- ward, though opposite, in front of the observer.

21.label: list_item
21.text: 2. Wecan proceed in “the finding of the position of the virtual, apparent form” (cognitione loci forme non vere apparentis [where non vere has been translated as “virtual”’).

21.label: text
21.text: This concerns two cardinal arguments, which we will now analyze

21.label: text
21.text: Let us begin by specifying that the original point of view sees straightforward the image associated with the virtual object. In this operation of straightforward positioning, the associated image conserves this meta (destination point) (anc ‘metam in the Latin), which will be necessary to indicate on the mirror by means of “a sign” (nutus), to which the image will remain anchored in its double correspondence to two objects: the real one and the virtual one.

21.label: text
21.text: Through the orthogonal visual ray, which goes from the pupil to the mirror and which corresponds to our principal ray, pass all of the planes of the reflection: in our case, the four planes 00'Ta-a, 00’Tb-b, 0O'Te-c, 0O'Td-d, which are per- pendicular to the mirror and contain both the original visual rays and the refracted segments. However, it is toward the meta (destination point), which is the point 0’, that all of the images tend and flow as into a “pivot” or into a “vanishing point,” as well as the portions of the images, of the straight objective lines orthogonal to the mirror, placed both on this side and on the other side of it, since they have the virtual extension on the

21.text: sot 99/10.1017/€809781139198905.007 Pushed online by Cambridge University Press

22.label: caption
22.text: a1 The great law of reflection: The order of the sequences. Note: For the order of the sequences and their symmetry, see Chapter 1, Figure 10.

22.label: text
22.text: opposite side. Upon these images of straight lines (Fig. 91) are also found all of the associated images of the objective points and of the respective virtual opposite ones. By placing us in front of the traced form, Ptolemy thus places us in front of this meta (destination point), which corresponds exactly ~ I repeat ~ to the principal vanishing point, to say it in modern terms, of all the orthogonal lines to the picture plane.

22.label: text
22.text: This vanishing point also constitutes the “pivot” to which are linked the two images: the reflected one (or specular) and the straightforward one (or perspective) of the virtual cube.

23.label: section_header
23.text: 8. THE POSITION OF THE VIRTUAL APPARENT FORM

23.label: text
23.text: Let us continue to focus our attention on the meaning of the “associated” image, in which coincide the reflected image and the straightforward image of the virtual object. One may draw three principal fundamentals from this paragraph:

23.label: list_item
23.text: 1, The images of straight lines, or portions of the same lines, erected upon the flat mirrors, are seen according to straight lines without bending (videntur secundum rectitudinem sine proclivitate): this important factor implies that these images are not curved or arched (Fig. 91).

23.label: list_item
23.text: 2. The images of straight lines, or portions of the same lines, erected upon flat mirrors, “appear positioned on the same side toward which the objects move” (apparent translate ad eandem partem ad quam res moventur); that is why, for example, if one has the sequence 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, et cetera, which begins to part from the mirror, this sequence will have to part in this same exact order also from the opposite side beyond the mirror.

23.label: list_item
23.text: 3. Through the order of the rectilinear sequence, one can find the position of the apparent “not true” object, that is to say, the “virtual” object (ita procedimus et in cognitione loci forme non vere apparentis).

23.label: text
23.text: Let us explain by means of examples what this implies. If we have a drawing, represented by simple lines and simple points, one can immediately draw its reverse, or vice versa, if we have its reverse, one can immediately draw its obverse with the cor- respondence now described: this is the simple law of symme- try. Applying this concept, for example, the real points Te, A, B, et cetera, on one side, will be set on the opposite side always in the order Tc, A", B", starting from the mirror (Fig. 92) ~ a phenomenon that generates the turning over of the sequence and therefore the reversal of the square, with the inversion of the respective arrows.

23.label: text
23.text: From the simple reduction of the spatial summary onto a plane (Fig. 93), it is possible to further verify the facility with

Furthermore, as the head, or the beginning of the viewpoint, has a terminus and a single position, in the same way the con- stitution of the images must occur according to a single and

26.text: same point that has a determined position, which must natu- rally be upon the perpendicular line from the eye to the mirror. ‘The origin of the viewpoint, which moves in any way upon this perpendicular line, or which shifts away from it, generates many discrepancies in the vision.

26.label: text
26.text: To show the forms, or rather the images of the things that appear straightforward: this is the true intent of what Ptolemy sets forth in paragraph 65.” The Latin says expressly ut pate- ant forme omnium rerum que videntur aut recte aut aliter. These matters, Ptolemy specifies, would be such to require a book apart, but he will operate by limiting himself to only the most relevant points. Thus, the purpose of the theory of flat mirrors consists, for Ptolemy and also for us, in constructing a straight- forward image of that virtual one, under the conditions that we will now illustrate.

26.label: text
26.text: At paragraph 66,” the premise is made that when one speaks of the viewpoint, one must understand the vertex of the pyr- amid of rays, by means of which one sees, and that when one speaks of the image of a line perpendicular to the plane of the mirror, one must understand the line that is the common inter- section of the plane of the mirror and of the plane orthogonal to it, containing the visual ray and the refracted ray.

26.label: text
26.text: In paragraph 67, it is reiterated that the appearances of things are to be considered in relation to the distance, to the quantity, and to the position as well as in making reference to only one vision at a time.

26.label: text
26.text: Paragraph 68” describes the straight line ABG, which locates the surface of a flat mirror, the viewpoint D, and the object E (Fig. 94). Let the visual ray that exits from the viewpoint D bend, in going toward E, at equal angles in respect to the mir- ror, and let DBE be the ray (which fractures at B on the mirror). It is affirmed that no other ray, among those which proceed from point D, fractures toward E at equal angles. Therefore, the singularity of the ray DBE is affirmed. In paragraphs 69 and

31.text: 13. THE REFLECTED IMAGE OF THE REAL OBJECT AND THE STRAIGHTFORWARD IMAGE OF THE VIRTUAL OBJECT COINCIDE

31.label: text
31.text: According to paragraph 97, in the flat mirrors the reflected images “do not differ from those of the objects placed frontally which are seen straightforward” (non differri a subiectis rebus que recte videntur), because the manner of being of the first images is similar to that of the latter images.

31.label: text
31.text: It is clearly shown that the situs adversus, the “opposite position,” is the position where the virtual objects are arranged inverted (Figs. 100, 101)

Walls are painted in the upper registers with architectural elements of the house and doors, the parts above wider than the parts below (the Latin reads superiores partes videntur ampliores), although there is not, in reality, nar- rowing or expansion of any kind in those upper parts.

34.label: text
34.text: Human beings, Ptolemy informs us, became accustomed to painting these transformations in conformity with a well- defined and stable position of the observer: a phrase that in Latin reads Hoc enim consueverunt homines facere, ut positio sit bene disposita et firma.” This position is the fixed and immuta- ble viewpoint that every perspective must have, the point that Ptolemy taught how to establish and to specify by means of the theory of the principal ray and of the meta.

34.label: text
34.text: Here, as a consequence, is to be found the theoretical jus- tification, in accordance with the mathematical and geometric point of view, for the architectural wall paintings executed at Rome and Pompeii, before a.p. 79. Such paintings would have been found in any other city of the Roman Empire around the third or fourth decade of the second century of our era.

34.label: section_header
34.text: 15. THE THREE PROJECTIONS OF THE SPHERE PRESENT IN PTOLEMY

34.label: text
34.text: Through the theory of mirrors, Ptolemy reduced the three- dimensional reality of objects to a plane, but beyond this he also treated the projection onto a plane of the celestial vault and the terrestrial sphere. In fact, he constructed celestial and terrestrial maps based on very precise geometrical principles. ‘The sphere, which is impossible to develop on a plane, is also particularly difficult to represent. Ptolemy found the images through exact projections, using a center and a projection plane ~ those very elements which we have studied in the the- ory of mirrors.

34.label: text
34.text: First of all, he fixed the essential elements of reference for the terrestrial sphere ~ the axis, the poles, the equator, the parallels, and the meridians. And, consequently, for the celestial sphere, which is considered an immense enlarge- ment of the terrestrial sphere, he established the celestial meridians, the celestial equator, the ecliptic, the equinoc- tial colure, and the astronomical horizon ~ all elements that serve to establish both geographical and astronomical point coordinates.

36.text: 103. Ptolemy's geography 2: The projection of the terrestrial sphere from a point in space taken from the parallel through Syene

36.label: text
36.text: In Geographia,** Ptolemy examines the representation of the terrestrial sphere, in order to produce a map of the earth. He projects the sphere onto a vertical plane, passing through the center of the earth, from a point in space taken from the paral- lel plane of Syene (Figs. 102, 103). The area he delimits covers the oikoumene of the ancients, the world as then known. In producing such a boundary, Ptolemy designed the elliptical projections of the equatorial circle below and of the parallel circle above, the latter passing through Thule. This is a classi cal scenographic or perspectival projection.
